While I would question the neccessity of a separate project just to be able to
get a client code generated, I tried to comply with the Wizard, went back and
entered a new project name, yet both "next" and "finish" buttons remained disabled.

My setup:
http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/download.php?file=/eclipse/downloads/drops/S-3.1M4-200412162000/eclipse-SDK-3.1M4-win32.zip
http://download.eclipse.org/tools/emf/downloads/drops/2.1.0/I200412160800/emf-sdo-xsd-SDK-I200412160800.zip
http://download.eclipse.org/tools/gef/downloads/drops/I-I20041216-200412160200/GEF-SDK-I20041216.zip
http://download.eclipse.org/tools/ve/downloads/drops/R-1.0.2-200412091401/JEM-runtime-1.0.2.zip
http://download.eclipse.org/webtools/downloads/drops/S-1.0M2-200412230036/wtp-1.0M2.zip

The EJB Client project creation during EJB Project creation is optional.  If you
choose to create a seperate ejb client project, all ejb bean classes will be
placed in the ejb project and the interfaces when generated should go to the ejb
client project.  The client project is therefore simply a java project
containing the public interfaces of the beans...this is good code practice
especially when references exist between two ejb projects in different ears.  If
you want your interfaces and bean class to be in the same project simply do not
create an ejb client project.
Please open a seperate defect concerning how you actually got the below stack
trace....as when =I attempt to create an ejb project with a client, it will not
allow me to finish if the name is the same as the ejb project.
Changed Version field given new release numbering.
